results.title: The Inside Joke That Became Trump’s Big Lie
results.abstract: The lie that Trump won the 2020 election has grown so powerful because it is yoked to an older deception: the idea that American politics is a joke.

results.title: The Enduring Wisdom of ‘Goodnight Moon’
results.abstract: It’s the first book many babies receive as a gift, and one of the few that parents will keep when their child is grown. Why does this 75-year-old story have such staying power?

results.adx_keywords: Travel and Vacations;Museums;Black People;Matthews, Tonya M;International African American Museum;Charleston (SC);South Carolina
results.title: ‘We Tell The Whole Truth’: A Talk With the Head of Charleston’s New African American Museum
results.abstract: The International African American Museum, opening early next year, will tell a story of joy, trauma and resiliency. Dr. Tonya Matthews discusses her role and the museum’s challenges.

media.caption: “We are clearly in a period of acceleration in our conversations around African American history, the African American journey, race and racial justice — and the museum is in the middle of that,” said Dr. Tonya Matthews, the president and chief executive of the International African American Museum, opening early next year in Charleston.

results.title: John Train, Paris Review Co-Founder and Cold War Operative, Dies at 94
results.abstract: His career, ranging from literature to finance to war, and from France to Afghanistan, seemed to cover every interest and issue of his exalted social class.

media.caption: John Train in an undated photo. A jocund hobbyist who ambled into bookish success, he was also an operator in high finance and world affairs — and, by one account, had ties to U.S. secret services.

results.title: Alan Alda on ‘M*A*S*H’: ‘Everybody Had Something Taken From Them’
results.abstract: As the acclaimed “situation tragedy” turns 50, the star reflects on its innovations: “The crazy behavior wasn’t just to be funny. It was a way of separating yourself for a moment from the nastiness.”

media.caption: Alan Alda starred in more than 250 episodes of “M*A*S*H,” which debuted on CBS on Sept. 17, 1972.
